p: Regarding ‘political will’, its inclusion in the Los Ríos workshop can be associated with ‘decentralisation’ and the perception of a lack of political will, in order to, achieve it. According to Waissbluth et al. ( 2007), Chilean political elites have historically considered that regions and municipalities do not have the capacity for managing greater responsibilities. Tagle ( 1985) argues that Chilean institutions are monopolised by politicians from the capital to the detriment of regional and local interests. This aspect allows us to connect the emergence of decentralisation and political will with the lack of territorialisation that, at the same time, could partially explain the lower participation rate of private sector and civil society.
